title: Lou Rees
text:
Lewis "Lou"/"Lew" Morgan Rees (7 January 1910 – 21 December 1976) was a Welsh <a href="List%20of%20dual-code%20rugby%20internationals">dual-code international</a> <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>, and professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1930s and 1940s. He played representative level rugby union (RU) for <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales</a>, and at club level for <a href="Treorchy%20RFC">Treorchy RFC</a> and <a href="Cardiff%20RFC">Cardiff RFC</a>, as a <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Flanker">flanker</a>, i.e. number 6 or 7, and representative level rugby league (RL) for <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Wales</a>, and at club level for <a href="Oldham%20R.L.F.C.">Oldham</a> (both pre- and post-<a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>) (<a href="List%20of%20Oldham%20R.L.F.C.%20players">Heritage № 306</a>), as a , i.e. number 8 or 10, during the era of contested <a href="Scrum%20%28rugby%29%23Rugby%20league">scrum</a>s.
Background.
Rees was born in <a href="Treherbert">Treherbert</a>, Wales, and he died aged 66 in <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a>.
International honours.
Lou Rees won a <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">cap</a> for <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales</a> (RU) while at Cardiff on Saturday 11 March 1933 against Ireland, and won 5 caps for <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Wales</a> (RL) in 1935–1938 while at Oldham.
